title: Banks are profiteering but no inquiry needed
text:
The big banks are profiteering but another inquiry isn't the answer and neither should the banks be broken up, according to a fortnightly poll of The Australian Financial Review's readers.

The banks' failure to pass on the rate cut in full led 55 per cent of the Financial Review's readers to conclude that the banks were "profiteering".

Despite this, 51 per cent of readers said a further inquiry was not required and close to 60 per cent believed forced divestment should not be pursued.

The big four came under fire this month after passing on just above half of the latest 25-basis point rate cut delivered on October 1 by the Reserve Bank.

This was followed by calls from former NAB and ANZ executive Joseph Healy to force the majors to divest some of their businesses.

Adding to the chorus of criticism, the competition regulator boss Rod Sims questioned the market power of banks in a recent parliamentary committee hearing, floating the need for an inquiry into the market power concentration in the sector.
description: The big banks are profiteering but should not be broken up, according to a fortnightly poll of The Australian Financial Review's readers.
